title: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, will an armed group from Afghanistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Afghanistan?
preds: I used the UNAMA report (https://unama.unmissions.org) as a baseline. Calculated the trend and standard deviations from that data. Trend value for 2019 is 3949 deaths. Standard deviation 440.

Unless it is a state-run engagement, I do not see a campaign that kills 1,000 people as it takes too much energy to do a mas killing of that size. The energy one speaks about is the weapon power it must be of a large proportion to do a mass killing of this scenario.

The trailing two months has an average of 19-20 civilians killed per week, according to the New York Times Afghan War Casualty Report, but many of them were killed in "night raids and air strikes" during the worst weeks, meaning that the base rate per week is currently lower. My best estimate for year's end is still 500ish.
I don't see a good reason to deviate much from the base rate here.

More digging on this question reveals what a humanitarian hell hole Afghanistan's been turned into. In the context of thousands of civilian deaths in a good year, this question seems too narrow to be useful. Do they expect us to do an IC-grade, cell-level analysis of groups + ops capable of killing 1000+ civilians at a go? To simplify, I'm limiting qualifying priors to civilian deaths due to a defined class (anti-gov forces, etc.), over "campaign" periods of no more than 3 months. I'm seeing a highest mode of 550±50, and this must be divided by at least two competing factions. This puts us at 250-300, or an exceedence ratio of 3.3-4x vs. our question threshold of 1000. A super-secret probability function solves these as 3-7%, or 5±2%.
Surprised at all the high numbers - they’re bad for business (attract attention).
Dumb money runs >= 44% consensus, smarter money much closer to 5%. Probability of annual civilian deaths exceeding 3.3x average ~2%.

Early Warning base rate is 24.1. No mention on Genocide Watch. ACLED civilian data for the last 2 years is just over 300. I think genocide on this scale in a tribal country so accustomed to war and as fragmented as Afghanistan is much less probability.
USA withdrawal of troops giving taliban more opportunities and courage

Clearly, random killings and other forms of violence are quite likely, but nothing suggests to me that a large=scale campaign will occur that soon.  With the rapid swings in policies and loyalties, though, anything is possible.
The detailed question is naive and misleading. Bombings in Afghanistan, by Isis or Taliban are largely indifferent to the victims.
ISIS  is a factor that  whose strength will depend on US presence of absence.
.I'm assuming that Blackwater is an armed group'
The Taliban will continue to target Afghan Gov't personnel not civilians.

The question is very specific in that it is asking about systemic killings of civilians, and NOT about civilian casualties.  The last time I can find where this happened (at the moment) and more than 1000 people were killed was the Sinjar massacre in 2014 (ISIS), before then the Pibar massacre in 2013 (Sudan). The Rabaa massacre was another potential, but the frequency of systemic killings is quite low, despite the large number of civilian deaths in war zones.  It seems that the Taleban is growing stronger in Afghanistan, and as such may want to carry out fewer attacks against civilians to boost its legitimacy. However, non state forces regularly target election campaigns with attacks (to lower turnout to lower the legitimacy of the elections) and the presidential election is due to be held on 20th July (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/12/afghan-presidential-elections-postponed-july-20-official-181230185336213.html). Attacks against polling stations are likely, with 300 in the 2018 election, but many of these were low in the number of people killed - the attacks would have to be very effective in order to get up to the 1000 threshold, and as far as I know this would be the first example of this happening in Afghanistan. Furthermore, this presidential election keeps getting postponed. There is a very very very outside chance than another non state actor such as ISISK decides that they have something to gain by committing a mass killing in Afghanistan, but they are a small group, and would have to do this in opposition to both the government, and the Taleban.
